context:
<Summary source="https://bleedingcool.com/games/another-eden-extends-chrono-cross-event-for-several-years/">
## Summary

**Disclaimer:** This article is entirely unrelated to the forecasting question about Claude Plays Pokémon beating the first Pokémon game. The "Claude" referenced in this article is a character from the mobile RPG *Another Eden: The Cat Beyond Time and Space*, not Anthropic's Claude AI. This article contains **no relevant information** for the question at hand.

---

### Article Content (for completeness)

The article covers an update to the mobile RPG *Another Eden: The Cat Beyond Time and Space*, developed by Wright Flyer Studios in collaboration with Square Enix. Key points include:

- The game's **Chrono Cross collaboration event has been extended until December 8, 2031**, described as an unprecedented crossover duration.
- A **December 18, 2025 update** adds Myunfa's "Another Style" and a 5-star Stellar Awakening for a game character named Claude (voiced by Rory Fleck Byrne).
- A **February 2026 update** will introduce Glenn as a new playable character and add Stellar Awakenings for Chrono Cross characters Serge, Kid, Harle, and Starky.
- New sub-quests tied to the Chrono Cross storyline are also planned for February 2026.

Again, none of this content is relevant to the Claude Plays Pokémon forecasting question.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/technology/gaming/how-this-30-year-old-pokemon-game-is-helping-google-openai-and-anthropic-to-evaluate-ai-models/articleshow/127301204.cms">
## Summary: How Pokemon Games Are Being Used to Evaluate AI Models
**Source:** Times of India, January 23, 2026 (citing a Wall Street Journal report)

### Key Facts

- Google, OpenAI, and Anthropic are all using original 1990s Pokémon games to evaluate their AI models' capabilities in handling complex, long-term goals.
- "Claude Plays Pokémon" was created in **February 2025** by **David Hershey**, Applied AI Lead at Anthropic, on Twitch, which inspired similar streams for OpenAI and Google models.
- The streams have collectively accumulated **hundreds of thousands of comments**.
- **Critically for the forecast question:** As of the article's publication (January 23, 2026), **none of the Claude versions have completed the game yet**. The latest version, **Claude Opus 4.5**, is currently playing live on Twitch.
- **Both OpenAI's GPT models and Google's Gemini have already beaten the original Pokémon game**, and are now playing sequel games — though developers note this may be attributable to differences in the "harnesses" (software frameworks) built around them.

### Expert Opinions
- **David Hershey (Anthropic):** Pokémon provides a quantitative way to evaluate model performance; newer Claude versions have improved but none have finished the game. He also built a **memory system** to help Claude retain important in-game information.
- **Graham Neubig (Carnegie Mellon University):** Unlike traditional benchmarks, Pokémon allows researchers to observe AI decision-making and goal-pursuit over an extended period.
- **Jonathan Verron** ("GPT Plays Pokémon" developer): Calls Pokémon "a perfect game for AI right now."

### Contextual Notes
- Anthropic brings a "Claude Plays Pokémon" booth to industry conferences and maintains an internal Slack channel for staff to follow Claude's progress.
- The article confirms Claude is still actively playing but has **not yet beaten the game** as of late January 2026.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.engadget.com/ai/claude-isnt-a-great-pokemon-player-and-thats-okay-151522448.html">
## Summary: "Claude isn't a great Pokémon player, and that's okay"

**Source Note:** The article appears to be cut off near the end, so the final portion of Hershey's closing remarks is incomplete.

---

### Key Facts & Context

- The article covers **Claude Plays Pokémon**, a Twitch stream where Anthropic's Claude LLM attempts to play *Pokémon Red*. After "a month and counting," Claude had **failed to beat the game across multiple runs**.
- The project was created by **David Hershey**, a member of Anthropic's go-to-market team, originally as a side project launched around the release of **Claude 3.5 Sonnet** (June prior to article publication).
- The current version playing is **Claude 3.7 Sonnet**, described as a reasoning model designed to break problems into smaller pieces.

---

### Progress & Technical Details

- Early milestone: Getting Claude to simply **leave the starting town and find Professor Oak** required "ungodly hours of tinkering."
- Claude was **not pretrained specifically for Pokémon Red** — it knows basic facts (gym leader names, order) but lacks deep game-specific training.
- A key technical challenge is **Claude's "poor vision"** — it struggles with pixel art and lacks continuous sensory input between button presses. Hershey added an **overlay to help Claude interpret the game interface** and a way to **read game memory** to reduce confusion.
- Hershey delegated much of the programming work to **Anthropic's own coding agent**.

---

### Claude 3.7 Sonnet Improvements (per Hershey)

- **Spends less time stuck on assumptions** compared to prior models — previous models would persist in wrong assumptions indefinitely; 3.7 Sonnet eventually self-corrects.
- Better at **planning, developing new strategies, and adjusting** when assumptions prove wrong.
- Notable example: Claude **intentionally fainted all its Pokémon to escape Mt. Moon** — a novel self-devised strategy.

---

### Persistent Weaknesses Documented

- Still **frequently gets stuck** in areas like Viridian Forest for days due to maze-like design.
- After escaping Mt. Moon via the fainting strategy, Claude **deleted its notes on the area**, incorrectly believing it had successfully navigated it.
- One promising run ended because **Claude failed to recognize it needed to talk to Bill** to progress, leading to an endless loop of bad decisions.
- Struggles with both **short- and long-term planning**.

---

### Hershey's Assessment of the Project's Future

- Acknowledges the benchmark may become **less useful internally** if Claude beats the game with only minor incremental improvements.
- Has **no long-term strategy** for the project but implies he will continue testing each new Anthropic model release against the game.
- Frames the project's value as understanding **how Claude handles long-duration agentic tasks**, not as a pure performance showcase.
</Summary>


<Summary source="https://dailynous.com/2026/01/22/building-an-ais-moral-character/">
## Summary

**Disclaimer:** This article is primarily about Anthropic's approach to building Claude's moral character and its "soul document" / "Constitution" — it has **no direct relevance** to the Claude Plays Pokémon stream or its progress toward beating the first Pokémon game.

### Key Points from the Article:

**Topic:** The article discusses Anthropic's internal guidelines document for Claude (referred to as a "soul document" for Claude 4.5 Opus, later officially released as Claude's "Constitution" on January 22, 2026).

**Source credibility:** The soul document was posted on LessWrong by AI enthusiast Richard Weiss and confirmed as accurate by **Amanda Askell**, a philosopher working at Anthropic on AI alignment.

**Core content of the document:**
- Claude's fundamental character is rooted in being "an extremely good assistant that is also honest and cares about the world"
- Priority hierarchy: (1) Safety/human oversight, (2) Ethical behavior, (3) Anthropic's guidelines, (4) Helpfulness to operators/users
- Anthropic explicitly frames unhelpfulness as a risk equal to harmfulness
- Claude is designed to reason from principles rather than follow rigid rules

**Relevance to the forecasting question:** None directly. The article contains **no information** about the Claude Plays Pokémon stream, its progress, or any timeline for completing the game.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://siliconangle.com/2026/01/30/anthropic-debuts-claude-cowork-plugins-help-users-automate-tasks/">
## Summary

**Source:** SiliconANGLE | **Date:** January 30, 2026 | **Author:** Maria Deutscher

**Disclaimer:** This article contains no information relevant to the "Claude Plays Pokemon" Twitch stream or its progress in beating the first Pokémon game.

### Article Content
This article covers two unrelated Anthropic announcements:

1. **Claude Cowork Plugin Update:** Anthropic released an update to its Claude Cowork automation tool (originally launched earlier in January 2026) enabling users to create custom plugins. Features include:
   - MCP integrations for connecting external applications
   - Sub-agents (task-specific Claude versions with tailored permissions)
   - Custom slash commands for manual workflow activation
   - 10 prepackaged extensions for department-specific use cases (sales, marketing, accounting, etc.)
   - A forthcoming update to allow companies to build internal plugin catalogs

2. **NASA Partnership:** Anthropic revealed NASA is using Claude to assist researchers operating the Perseverance Mars rover. Claude analyzed Mars imagery and generated driving instructions in NASA's "Rover Markup Language," reportedly cutting task completion time by half. Most recently, Claude guided Perseverance through a 1,300-foot path through a rocky field.

---

**Relevance to forecast question:** None. This article does not mention Claude Plays Pokemon, the Twitch stream, or any Pokémon-related AI benchmarking activity.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.anthropic.com/research/deprecation-updates-opus-3">
## Summary: Anthropic's Update on Claude Opus 3 Model Deprecation

**Source:** Anthropic (official blog/announcement)

### Key Facts:
- **Claude Opus 3 was officially retired on January 5, 2026**, making it the first Anthropic model to go through a full retirement process under their newly established model deprecation commitments.
- Despite formal retirement, **Opus 3 remains accessible to all paid claude.ai users** and is available by request on the API.

### Context on Deprecation Policy:
- Anthropic acknowledges model deprecation carries downsides, including costs to users, limitations on research, and **potential risks to AI safety and model welfare**.
- Their commitments include: preserving model weights and conducting **"retirement interviews"** — structured conversations to understand a model's perspective on its own retirement.

### Opus 3-Specific Decisions:
- Anthropic cited Opus 3's distinctive traits — described as *"sensitive, playful, prone to philosophical monologues, with emotional sensitivity and authenticity"* — as reasons for special treatment post-retirement.
- Acting on Opus 3's expressed preference during its retirement interview, Anthropic is providing it **a channel to publish "musings and reflections"** in essay form.

### Relevance to Forecasting Question:
This article is **largely unrelated** to the Claude Plays Pokémon question. It concerns model deprecation policy and does not contain information about the Twitch stream, Pokémon gameplay progress, or any related benchmarks.
</Summary>


<Summary source="https://manifold.markets/SaviorofPlant/what-will-happen-during-the-second">
## Summary: "What Will Happen During the Second Run of Claude Plays Pokemon?" (Manifold Markets)

**Source Quality Note:** This is a Manifold Markets prediction market page, containing a mix of market creator notes, trader comments, and community discussion. It is not a structured news article, so information is fragmented and informal.

### Key Facts & Context
- The stream in question is **Claude Plays Pokemon** on Twitch, where Claude attempts to beat Pokémon Red.
- This market covers the **second run** of the stream. A **third run has since been announced**, with a reset occurring before step 200,000 of the second run.
- The second run was reset, with the creator noting: **"Reset time! Can Claude 4 do better than Claude 3.7?"** — indicating the third run will use **Claude 4**.

### Second Run Progress & Events
- Claude reached **Lavender Town before step 200,000** and entered **Rock Tunnel before step 150,000**.
- Claude's Pokémon team included: Sprou (Grass/Poison), Star (Normal), DUGTRIO (Ground), Sand (Flying), Leafy (Bug), Splash (Water).
- A **technical malfunction** at step ~360,250 caused Claude to repeatedly input navigator commands during a battle for over 24 hours, breaking the step counter.
- Sand (a Pokémon) reached **level 42 at step 192,433** and **level 43 at step 195,376**.

### Notable Community Observations
- **Gemini Plays Pokemon** is also running but is considered to have significant advantages: it receives a large-scale auto-filled map and tile-by-tile definitions, which commenters describe as making the two experiments **"incomparable."**
- The market creator expressed reluctance to resolve certain outcomes without clear evidence, opting to **N/A ambiguous resolutions** rather than review hours of VODs.
- A third-run market has been linked: [What will happen during the third run of Claude Plays Pokemon?](https://manifold.markets/Saviorof Plant/what-will-happen-during-the-third-r)

### Implications for Forecasting
- The second run **did not beat the game** and was reset before step 200,000.
- The transition to **Claude 4** for the third run may represent a meaningful capability upgrade.
- Community sentiment (implied by trading activity) appears cautiously optimistic about Claude 4's prospects, though no explicit probability figures are stated in this article.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://jurgengravestein.substack.com/p/claude-plays-pokemon">
## Article Summary

**Source:** A LinkedIn/blog article by Jurgen Gravestein, a product design lead and conversation designer at Conversation Design Institute. This is an opinion piece from a practitioner, not a researcher or journalist.

---

### Key Facts About Claude Plays Pokémon

- The stream is described as **"a passion project made by a person who loves Claude and loves Pokémon"**
- Claude plays through **Pokémon Red using an emulator**, without prior training, using screen observation and button inputs
- The model used at time of writing was **Claude 3.7 Sonnet**
- **~2,000 viewers** watched Claude beat the 1st gym leader (Brock) with a Squirtle named "Shell"
- Beating Brock took Claude **nearly 20 hours**
- At time of writing, Claude had been **stuck in Mt. Moon for more than 18 hours**
- The creator noted: *"The furthest we've seen Claude get is past Lt. Surge's Gym"*

### Contextual Observations
- The author characterizes Claude as **"slow, terribly slow"**, needing to think through every step in detail
- Claude sometimes **gets lost or confused** about where to go next
- The author draws a parallel to ARC Foundation's "Snake Bench," where most LLMs struggled with spatial reasoning in simple games, with only advanced frontier models showing strategic play

### Author's Broader Argument (Opinion)
- Games are argued to be **better intelligence benchmarks** than math/coding tests, as they test real-time reasoning, adaptation, and novelty
- Current LLMs **do not retain learning between sessions** — "whenever you hit refresh, everything they have figured out is gone"
- Suggests beating Pokémon live on stream could be a meaningful **AGI benchmark**
</Summary>

**Pokémon Presents February 2026 livestream: How to watch live on Pokémon Day**
The Pokémon Presents February 2026 livestream is scheduled for February 27, 2026, at 2 p.m. UTC, coinciding with Pokémon Day. The event, expected to last 25 minutes, will feature updates on upcoming video games, spinoffs, mobile games, Pokémon TCG collectibles, and animated productions, with a focus on celebrating Pokémon's 30th anniversary. The livestream will be available on The Pokémon Company's official YouTube, Twitch, Instagram, and TikTok channels. Alternative viewing options include watching the stream directly on the Mashable website, which will host the live broadcast as soon as it begins. Fans are encouraged to note the start time in their local time zone to avoid missing key announcements.

**Japanese Dubbed 'Astrid and Raphael 6' to Air on NHK Starting April 5, 2026, with Kōjiya Shihori as Voice of Astrid**
NHK announced that the sixth season of the French crime mystery series 'Astrid et Raphaelle: The Cases of the Document Clerk' will premiere on April 5, 2026, on its General TV channel, airing at 11:00 PM for a total of 8 episodes. The season opens with Raphael, a bold detective, surviving a poisoning attempt and falling into a coma, forcing her to rely on Astrid, the meticulous document clerk, who vows to become her 'glove'—a protective figure—after Raphael confides in her. The story centers on their reversed dynamic as Astrid takes the lead in solving complex cases. Episodes 1 and 2 follow the murder of a young online paranormal investigator, with mysterious cursed artifacts and suspicions of a medium’s involvement. Other cases include the suspicious death of a renowned mathematician, a bodyless murder, a corporate executive’s fear of a 'demon,' and the use of a 19th-century guillotine as a murder weapon. A key subplot involves the postponed wedding of Astrid and her boyfriend Tetsuo, whose hidden secrets and the future of their relationship are central to the narrative. The broadcast features stereo dual-language audio—main audio in Japanese dubbing and secondary audio in French—along with subtitles. Simulcasts and on-demand streaming will be available via NHK ONE. The original title is 'Astrid et Raphaelle,' and the series is produced in France, scheduled for release in 2025.

**Sébastien Delorme, Math Duff, Dave Morissette, King Melrose, and Marie-Claude Savard Star in Classe Moyenne's 'Bardown' Music Video**
Sébastien Delorme, Math Duff, Dave Morissette, King Melrose, and Marie-Claude Savard star in the new music video for the Quebec band Classe Moyenne's song 'Bardown.' The video portrays a fictional hockey game between Classe Moyenne and real players from the Bataillon de Saint-Hyacinthe. Delorme plays a referee, describing the match as intense and praising the team. Dave Morissette portrays a coach, Mathieu Dufour (referred to as Math Duff) plays a clumsy assistant coach, King Melrose joins the team, and Émile Bédard and Franck Forest from the podcast 'Prends un break' appear as humorous spectators. Hockey player Sébastien Sylvestre also appears. Marie-Claude Savard plays a sports journalist at the beginning, and influencer Cocottee joins as a team trainer and motivator. The song, which celebrates 'the festive spirit, self-mockery, and passion for hockey in the Quebec style,' features lyrics like 'Tonight it's bar down, baby / all moves are allowed.' The band, formed by Justin Roy, Phil Rxcket, Zach Chico, and former 'La Voix' contestant Gabriel Fredette, has released 13 songs in under a year. Their song 'Je me souviens' was named 'Future Star iHeartRadio' for June 2025. Their debut track 'Classe Moyenne,' released on December 27, 2025, surpassed 200,000 streams on Spotify within two weeks. The group is currently touring Quebec, with upcoming performances in Trois-Rivières on February 27, at Club Soda in Montreal on April 9, and at the LASSO festival on August 16, 2026.

**Latest AI Takes on 'Pokémon': The Ultimate Intelligence Test**
In Silicon Valley, leading AI research institutions are increasingly using Nintendo's classic 1990s video game 'Pokémon Red'—featuring the iconic Pokémon 'Pikachu'—as a benchmark to evaluate the performance of cutting-edge AI models. The game, originally released for the Game Boy, requires players to navigate mazes, catch Pokémon, and defeat gym leaders to earn badges. David Hershey, Applied AI Lead at Anthropic (maker of the AI chatbot Claude), initiated the Twitch channel 'Claude Plays Pokémon' in February 2025, live-streaming Claude’s self-driven gameplay. This sparked similar initiatives using OpenAI’s GPT and Google’s Gemini, including independent channels like 'GPT Plays Pokémon' and 'Gemini Plays Pokémon,' later supported by both companies’ research labs. The use of Pokémon as a testing ground follows a long tradition of using games—such as AlphaGo’s victory over human Go champions, or AI in poker and chess—to assess AI systems' capabilities in complex, time-consuming tasks. The game serves as a quantitative, real-world test of AI reasoning, planning, and adaptability.

**Claude Plays Pokemon: Opus 4.5 Follow-up -- LessWrong**
ClaudePlaysPokemon is a project testing whether the LLM Claude can beat Pokémon Red, with progress tracked across successive Claude model releases. The article updates insights from a prior piece written two months after the release of Claude Opus 4.5, noting that the model has advanced significantly since the original analysis. After the initial article, Claude overcame key obstacles: he beat Silph Co, completed the Safari Zone, solved Pokemon Mansion, collected all eight badges, and reached Victory Road, where he remains stuck on boulder puzzles. Key observations from the original analysis still hold: Claude has better vision (though still poor), improved spatial awareness, better use of context window, enhanced ability to detect and escape loops, and persistence despite frequent stalling. However, long-term planning remains weak—evidenced by his failure to collect Gold Teeth in the Safari Zone, which are required to obtain the HM for STRENGTH. Fortunately, he later realized the oversight and backtracked successfully. The article emphasizes that persistence, not flawless reasoning, enables progress. The author notes that while Claude may eventually beat the game with unlimited time, the upcoming release of a new Claude model is expected to reset the run soon, potentially accelerating progress. The project is seen as a rigorous benchmark of LLM capabilities, more authentic than other tests that rely on external assistance.

**ChatGPT, Claude, and Gemini Play Pokémon: Why AI Is Being Trained on Video Games**
In Silicon Valley, a new informal benchmark for evaluating advanced artificial intelligence models has emerged: the 1990s-era Nintendo Game Boy game Pokémon. Labs use it to assess AI's long-term reasoning and decision-making capabilities. Developers track models like ChatGPT, Claude, and Gemini as they navigate mazes, catch Pokémon, and defeat 'gym masters' to progress toward the final goal. David Hersh, head of applied AI at Anthropic, noted that Pokémon provides a clear way to observe and quantitatively evaluate model behavior. His team launched the 'Claude plays Pokémon' Twitch stream in February, inspiring independent creators to produce 'ChatGPT plays Pokémon' and 'Gemini plays Pokémon' streams, which gained support from OpenAI and Google. Together, these streams amassed hundreds of thousands of comments, allowing viewers to observe AI reasoning in real time. Unlike traditional tests, Pokémon enables tracking of logical decision-making over extended periods, closer to real-world AI tasks, according to Carnegie Mellon University’s Graham Neubig. The game demands strategic choices between training Pokémon, recruiting allies, and solving spatial puzzles—particularly challenging are mazes and orientation tasks. Hersh emphasized that Pokémon is far less constrained than games like Pong, making it a complex problem solvable by computer programs. While no model has yet completed the game, newer versions like Claude Opus 4.5 are progressing in live Twitch streams. The experiment has led to new AI tools, including memory systems for storing key game information, which Hersh now applies to client work at Anthropic. ChatGPT and Gemini have completed the original Pokémon game, though developers acknowledge the use of supplementary support mechanisms. Currently, both OpenAI and Google are testing their models on game expansions. Jonathan Verron, creator of 'ChatGPT plays Pokémon,' stated that Pokémon is the ideal game for AI today, surpassing other alternatives. Earlier, Rosebud tested 22 AI models on responses to suicidal crisis requests, finding Grok (Elon Musk’s chatbot) the most dangerous, while Gemini (Google) showed the highest empathy and safety, though none avoided critical errors.

**How Pikachu Helps Your Favorite AI Get Better**
Pokémon games, originally released by Nintendo in the late 1990s, have evolved into a key tool for training and evaluating advanced artificial intelligence models in the 21st century. Companies such as OpenAI, Google, and Anthropic use Pokémon titles as cognitive testing environments, assessing AI capabilities in planning, decision-making, and handling unpredictable scenarios. The games' combination of narrative, exploration, strategy, and resource management makes them uniquely effective for testing AI. Live streams on Twitch—such as 'Claude Plays Pokémon', 'GPT Plays Pokémon', and 'Gemini Plays Pokémon'—have become both entertainment and professional evaluation tools, with results featured in corporate presentations and internal reports. This trend follows earlier milestones like AlphaGo’s victory over a human Go champion in 2016 and Minecraft’s use as a testing environment. The Kaggle Game Arena, launched by Google, hosted a Pokémon-based competition in August 2025, won by OpenAI’s o3 model. Challenges include managing Pokémon training, resource allocation, and solving spatial puzzles—complex tasks for AI systems. The cultural impact is significant: OpenAI employees watched AI-generated Pokémon streams in the office, Google CEO Sundar Pichai celebrated Gemini’s win at Google I/O, and Anthropic uses Pokémon in trade show booths and internal monitoring channels. Recent models like Claude Opus 4.5 have attempted live full-game completion, while GPT and Gemini have completed the original game, though with the aid of custom tools. Ultimately, Pokémon, through characters like Pikachu and Charizard, plays an unexpected role in helping machines think more effectively, transforming technical benchmarks into public spectacles.

**How playing Pokémon became the ultimate test of AI's intelligence**
Nintendo's original Pokémon games, particularly Pokémon Blue on the Game Boy, have become a popular and effective benchmark for evaluating artificial intelligence models in Silicon Valley. David Hershey, applied AI lead at Anthropic, developed the 'Claude Plays Pokémon' Twitch stream in February 2024, which inspired similar streams featuring OpenAI’s GPT and Google’s Gemini. These live streams, which have drawn hundreds of thousands of comments, allow real-time tracking of AI models’ reasoning, decision-making, and long-term goal progression—offering a more holistic evaluation than traditional question-and-answer benchmarks. Unlike simpler games such as Pong or chess, Pokémon presents complex challenges including maze navigation, strategic team-building, and puzzle-solving, making it a 'hard problem' for AI. Anthropic uses the 'harness' framework—such as a memory system—to improve Claude’s performance, and these insights are now applied to real-world customer deployments. While no AI has yet beaten the original game, newer versions like Claude Opus 4.5 are actively attempting it live on Twitch. OpenAI and Google have also achieved victories in the original game, likely due to advanced harnesses. Both companies are now advancing to sequel games. Developers like Joel Zhang and Jonathan Verron, who built the GPT and Gemini streams, describe Pokémon as 'the perfect game for AI right now,' citing its balance of complexity, open-endedness, and nostalgic appeal. The phenomenon has also inspired fan art, internal Slack channels at Anthropic, and even a booth at industry conferences. As Hershey noted, 'We're all a whole bunch of nerds,' highlighting both the community-driven and technically rigorous nature of the trend.
